channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Sheinbaum Disputes US Money Laundering Claims Against Mexican Banks
item.description: Mexico’s president responded defiantly to US measures that could cripple three prominent local banks on accusations of potential money laundering tied to drug trafficking, arguing she’s seen no evidence to support the crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Mexico's president Claudia Sheinbaum during the Association of Banks of Mexico convention in Nuevo Vallarta, Mexico, on May 8.

item.title: Ramaphosa Fires Deputy Minister, Strains S. Africa Coalition
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa fired a deputy minister from the second-largest party in the ruling coalition on Thursday, a move that renews strain on the stability of his administration.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA - JULY 03: Andrew Whitfield during the swearing-in ceremony of the new national executive members at Cape Town International Convention Centre on July 03, 2024 in Cape Town, South Africa. The new National Executive constitutes the 7th Democratic Administration as a Government of National Unity comprising a diversity of political parties as an outcome of the national and provincial elections held on Wednesday, 29 May 2024. (Photo by Misha Jordaan/Gallo Images via Getty Images)

item.title: Canada Steel Firms Say Weak Tariff Response Risks Wider Layoffs
item.description: A group of Canadian steel producers said the government’s plan to restrict foreign steel imports isn’t strong enough and warned that the industry is set to shed thousands more jobs because of US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: An employee passes in front of steel coils at a galvanizing mill in Hamilton, Ontario.

item.title: Hegseth Berates Media as Questions Linger on Iran Strike Impact
item.description: US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth used a press briefing Thursday to berate the media over reports that questioned the effectiveness of strikes on Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

media:content.media:description: Pete Hegseth during a news conference at the Pentagon on June 26. Photographer: Andrew Harnik/Getty Images

item.title: Abrego Garcia Remains in Jail Amid Dispute Over Release
item.description: Kilmar Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man who the Trump administration mistakenly deported to a prison in El Salvador, remains in legal limbo after defeating a bid by the government to keep him locked up on criminal charges.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Hurtado

media:content.media:description: Katheryn Millwee holds a portrait of Kilmar Abrego Garcia outside the federal courthouse, Wednesday, June 25, 2025, in Nashville, Tenn. (AP Photo/George Walker IV)

item.title: Trump’s Threat of More Tariffs Makes US Trade Partners Wary of Signing Deals
item.description: Tariff negotiations with the Trump administration are running into roadblocks, as partners including Japan, India and the European Union balk at signing deals without knowing how badly they’ll be hit by separate levies on exports including chips, drugs and steel.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott, Yoshiaki Nohara, Shruti Srivastava, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Trucks enter the Port of Los Angeles.

item.title: Harvard Academic Who Met Top Chinese Diplomat Sees US Trade Breakthrough Soon
item.description: A Harvard University academic who met with top Chinese officials including Foreign Minister Wang Yi said he expects the US and China to agree to a memorandum of understanding on trade as early as next week.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu

media:content.media:description: Gantry cranes and shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, May 14, 2025. China and the US agreed to temporarily lower tariffs levied against each other's products — the first major de-escalation in the trade row that was touted by US President Donald Trump as a "total reset" of bilateral ties. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: French Premier Says Agreement Close on Some Pension Law Changes
item.description: French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou said Thursday an agreement is within reach on some changes to the contentious pension reform.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Prime Minister Francois Bayrou

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Signs New Tax Laws in Latest Reform Push
item.description: Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has signed four new tax laws, marking the latest chapter in his push to reform the economy of Africa’s most populous nation.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo, Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Bola Ahmed Tinubu

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Hits $250 Billion Health-Care Snag in Senate
item.description: A Republican plan to cut $250 billion in Medicaid and other health-care spending hit a procedural roadblock in the Senate Thursday, complicating efforts to pass Donald Trump’s massive tax and spending package.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang, Erik Wasson, Erin Durkin

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators during a markup of US President Donald Trump's tax package in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. House Republicans want to impose work requirements on some Medicaid recipients up to 64 years old and impose more costs on some beneficiaries to help pay for President Donald Trump's planned sweeping tax package.

item.title: EU Firms Up Trade Strategy Ahead of Trump’s Tariff Deadline
item.description: European Union leaders are set to debate their strategy in response to President Donald Trump’s trade war, with the likely choices coming down to accepting an unbalanced deal or risking escalation by striking back.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero, Katharina Rosskopf, Sanne Wass

media:content.media:description: Multiple container ships docked at Hamburg Port.

item.title: Canada’s Budget Watchdog Urges Carney to Show Numbers as Spending Rises
item.description: Canada’s budget watchdog urged Prime Minister Mark Carney to release an update on the federal government’s finances soon or risk eroding the government’s credibility with investors.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Canada's prime minister Mark Carney

item.title: Mamdani Shock Gives NYC Mayor Adams a Shot at a Comeback
item.description: Andrew Cuomo’s loss is Eric Adams’ gain.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias, Nacha Cattan, Gregory Korte

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani and Eric Adams

item.title: Kenya Accuses Protesters of Terrorism After 16 People Killed
item.description: Kenya’s government labeled protests in which at least 16 people died this week as “terrorism” and vowed to bring to book the people who planned them.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Protesters run from the police during a demonstration in Nairobi, on June 25.

item.title: Pritzker Seeks Third Illinois Term With Eye Also on White House
item.description: Illinois Governor JB Pritzker unveiled his bid for a third term with an attempt to position himself as a champion of voters’ economic concerns and a foil to President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Singh, Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: Governor of Illinois JB Pritzker

item.title: Iran’s Khamenei Says US Intervention in War Achieved Nothing
item.description: Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei claimed victory in the war with Israel and said the US’s intervention achieved nothing, in his first comments since a ceasefire came into effect earlier this week.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes, Eltaf Najafizada

media:content.media:description: Khamenei

item.title: Russia Aims to Launch State Messenger to Compete With App Giants
item.description: Russia plans to launch a state-run messaging application that aims to host some government services, giving existing platforms like WhatsApp and Telegram a homegrown competitor in the country.
item.dc:creator: Sofia Sorochinskaia

media:content.media:description: Russian authorities have already blocked Facebook and the X social media platform, while throttling YouTube.

item.title: Vance to Headline $250,000 Nantucket Political Dinner
item.description: Vice President JD Vance is scheduled to headline a political fundraiser in Nantucket in July, according to a person familiar with the matter, courting the Massachusetts island’s wealthy summer crowd to bolster Republicans before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Cam Baker

media:content.media:description: US Vice President JD Vance during a swearing-in ceremony for Howard Lutnick, US commerce secretary, not pictured, in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, Feb. 21, 2025. Lutnick, approved on a Senate vote of 51-45 on Tuesday, will oversee a large department with responsibilities ranging from fisheries management to export controls.

item.title: EU Climate Push Comes Under Pressure With France Flagging Risks
item.description: The European Union’s interim climate plan for 2040 faces a pushback at a summit of the bloc’s leaders, where French President Emmanuel Macron plans to stress the need for competitive industry during the green transition.
item.dc:creator: Ewa Krukowska, Alberto Nardelli, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Electricity transmission towers and cables between wind turbines in Catalonia, Spain.

item.title: Starmer Recognizes Asking ‘a Lot’ of UK Firms With Tax Hikes
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer acknowledged the toll his tax increases have had on UK businesses, signaling a potential shift as his Labour government faces pressure to resist additional hikes that could exert a drag on an already sputtering economy.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Freya Jones

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer, UK prime minister, at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) Global Annual Conference in London, UK, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. The UK is seeking to increase the recognition of British professional certifications abroad, a move aimed at boosting the nation’s service-sector exports by making it easier for highly skilled employees to work for clients overseas.

item.title: RFK Jr. Pulls US Funding for Vaccines for the World’s Poorest
item.description: Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said the US will cut funding to the organization responsible for vaccinating children in poor countries, a move experts warned will result in unnecessary deaths.
item.dc:creator: Ashleigh Furlong

media:content.media:description: A Kenyan health worker receives a vaccine as part of a GAVI initiative in Nairobi.

item.title: Chile Catches Thousands of Workers Holidaying at State’s Expense
item.description: Using tactics that could have won her a prize for investigative journalism, Chile’s unassuming comptroller general is shaking up the nation’s sclerotic public sector in her war on waste.
item.dc:creator: Valentina Fuentes

media:content.media:description: Dorothy Perez Source: Presidencia de Chile

item.title: Why Iran’s Unaccounted for Uranium Worries Nuclear Experts
item.description: For those concerned about Iran becoming a nuclear-armed state, it’s essential to understand not just what the attacks by the US and Israel did to the country’s capacity to enrich uranium, but also its existing inventory of atomic fuel.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

item.title: Turkish Opposition Risks New Crisis as Ex-Leader Eyes Comeback
item.description: The former leader of Turkey’s main opposition party said he’s willing to return to the post if a court invalidates the vote that removed him, a move that could divide the opposition and derail its efforts to challenge President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: Firat Kozok, Baris Balci

media:content.media:description: Kemal Kilicdaroglu

item.title: India Rejects Joint Defense Statement at Key China-Led Summit
item.description: India declined to back a joint statement at the China-led Shanghai Cooperation Organization meet, marking a rare public rift within the security bloc and highlighting unresolved tensions following its near-war with Pakistan last month.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian Army soldiers march through the ceremonial Rajpath during the Republic Day parade in New Delhi, India, on Tuesday, Jan. 26, 2021. As India celebrated becoming a republic with a military parade, thousands of Indian farmers on tractors entered New Delhi escalating protests against new agricultural laws passed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government.

item.title: Oil-Price Surge Helps Angola Put Plan to Borrow From IMF on Hold
item.description: Angola won’t seek a loan from the International Monetary Fund for now, as Africa’s third-biggest crude producer benefits from rising oil prices.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: The IMF logo.

item.title: Starmer Discusses Easing UK Welfare Cuts With Labour Rebels
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer looks ready to water down another of the UK government’s key policies, offering concessions to stop Labour party colleagues derailing his reforms to Britain’s expensive welfare payments.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Julian Harris

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer

item.title: Spain’s Leader Calls US Levies ‘Doubly Unfair’ in Trade Spat
item.description: Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez defended his decision to break with his NATO allies over increases in military spending and called President Donald Trump’s tariffs on Spain “doubly unfair.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro, Ben Sills

media:content.media:description: Pedro Sanchez in Brussels on June 26. Photographer: Nicolas Tucat/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: German Lawmakers Back Merz’s €46 Billion Tax-Breaks Package
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s €46 billion ($53 billion) package of tax breaks was approved by Germany’s lower house of parliament, paving the way for the measures to get final ratification in the upper house on July 11.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz on June 26. Photographer: Nicolas Tucat/Getty Images

item.title: Italy’s Ferrovie to Seek Investors for High-Speed Rail Network, CEO Says
item.description: Italy’s state railway Ferrovie dello Stato SpA is moving ahead with plans to sell minority stakes in its high-speed train network, Chief Executive Officer Stefano Donnarumma said.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio, Daniele Lepido

media:content.media:description: Stefano Donnarumma Photographer: Stephanie Gengotti/Bloomberg
